runs.text: Display the Sound-Spelling Card for each sound(s). Use the following cards: short
u (bus), ch/tch, ph, sh, th, wh, ng, l-blends, r-blends, s-blends, 3-letter blends.
Point to the spelling, say the letter names and sound or sounds, and have students repeat.
Use the articulation videos for any sound students need more support with. Have students write the spelling or spellings as they say the sound.
Use the first two words in the first line.
What do you hear thats different in these two words? What do you see thats different?

Then have students chorally read the remaining words in each line. For the first time through the blending lines, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed spelling, stating the sound or sounds, having students repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Read Aloud: Animals Are All Around Us
Display the picture on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Display the Sound-Spelling Card for each sound(s). Use the following cards: short
u (bus), ch/tch, ph, sh, th, wh, ng, l-blends, r-blends, s-blends, 3-letter blends.
Have students write each spelling several times on paper or dry-erase board. Prompt them to say each sound each time they write its spelling.
Use the Lesson 1 Blending words to apply the skill.
Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed spelling, stating the sound or sounds, having student repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Write the high-frequency words one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Discuss known and unknown word parts.
What sounds do you hear in
? (/k/ /u/ /m/) What letters do you see? (c-o-m-e) The
/ sound, just like in the word
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.
Read Aloud: Creating a Healthy, Happy Home for Zoo Animals
Display the picture on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Display the Sound-Spelling Card for each sound(s). Use the following cards: short
u (bus), ch/tch, ph, sh, th, wh, ng, l-blends, r-blends, s-blends, 3-letter blends.
Have students write each spelling several times on paper or dry-erase board. Prompt them to say each sound each time they write its spelling.
Use the Lesson 2 Blending words to apply the skill.
Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud.
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequence of words.
State the Letter Card to change. For example, say:
spelling. What word did you make?
Repeat, but dont tell students which letter to change. For example, say:
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequence of words.
Display the Sound-Spelling Card for each sound(s). Review each spelling and key word: short
u (bus), ch/tch, ph, sh, th, wh, ng, l-blends, r-blends, s-blends, 3-letter blends.
Use the new blending lines. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words.
When completed, have students select two words. Ask them to write a sentence for each word on paper or a dry-erase board.
Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Dictate the following words for students to spell:
sun, such, much, lunch, bunch, bench

. Write the words on the board for students to self-correct. Note on each students Student Observation Form sound-spellings they struggle with. Include more words with these sound-spellings in upcoming lessons.
Write or show Phonics/Syllable Cards for the ending -
Read each one and have students repeat. Explain that a suffix is a word part that may be added to the end of a word. It can change the words meaning and part of speech.
. Model for students how to read the new word formed.
can show that an action is happening now, so
. Guide students to read each word and use it in a sentence to determine the new words meaning.
Display each word, and guide students to read it.
Model how to sort the words
Have student partners sort the remaining words at their seats.
When completed, have students tell you how to sort the words in the pocket chart. Then have students chorally read the words in each column of the sort.
Ask students what they notice about the words.
If necessary, point out that both short
usually appear in the middle of a word or syllable.
Encourage students to look for words with these patterns
while reading. Highlight these words as you encounter them.
Read Aloud: Meet Your New Neighbors
Display the pictures on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Display the Sound-Spelling Card for each sound(s). Review each spelling and key word: short
u (bus), ch/tch, ph, sh, th, wh, ng, l-blends, r-blends, s-blends, 3-letter blends.
Have students write each spelling several times on paper or dry-erase board. Prompt them to say each sound each time they write its spelling.

Use the new blending words to apply the skill. For the first time through, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Then discuss key features of each word to focus students attention on known (regular) and unknown (irregular) word parts.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequences of words.
Display the Sound-Spelling Card for each sound(s). Review each spelling and key word: short
u (bus), ch/tch, ph, sh, th, wh, ng, l-blends, r-blends, s-blends, 3-letter blends.
Have students write each spelling several times on paper or dry-erase board. Prompt them to say each sound each time they write its spelling.

Use the Lesson 6 blending words to apply the skill. Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud. Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed sound-spelling, stating it, having students repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Read, Build, Write: a, can, and, come, are, for, big, go, has, I

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards. Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud. Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Extend the learning with one or more of the following activities:
Provide a sentence starter or frame for each word. Have students write and complete the sentences. Then have them read their sentences to a partner (e.g.,
Make a word using Letter Cards. Have students read and spell aloud the word. Then mix the Letter Cards. Have students fix the spelling.
Display the Sound-Spelling Card for each sound(s). Review each spelling and key word: short
u (bus), ch/tch, ph, sh, th, wh, ng, l-blends, r-blends, s-blends, 3-letter blends.
Have students write each spelling several times on paper or dry-erase board. Prompt them to say each sound each time they write its spelling.
Use the Lesson 6 blending words to apply the skill. When completed, guide students to find and circle all the words with digraphs

to make a two-letter blend. What word did you make?

Read Aloud: Unexpected Frog and Toad Habitats
Display the pictures on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words consumers, hospitable, cocoon, reduce, and crevice, and check understanding.
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Display the Sound-Spelling Card for each sound(s). Review each spelling and key word: short
u (bus), ch/tch, ph, sh, th, wh, ng (ring), l-blends, r-blends, s-blends, 3-letter blends.
Use the Lesson 6 blending words to quickly review the skill.
When completed, have students select two words.
Ask them to write a sentence for each word on paper or a dry-erase board.
Revisit the sentences to model sentence expanding by adding details. Have students expand one of their sentences.
Read Aloud: Protecting One of the Worlds Biggest Wetlands
Display the pictures on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Use Phonics/Syllable Cards to model  how to add the inflectional ending
Guide students to read each word and discuss its meaning based on the ending added.
List the words as they form them. Have students use each word in a sentence to reinforce the meaning.
Have students select two of the words from the list and write sentences for them.
This word names a bone in your chest.
to name something a baby sleeps in.
to two letters to make a word that means break
to make a word that is a frame or stand used to hold things.
to make a word that means stone or pebble.
Read, Build, Write: a, can, and, come, are, for, big, go, has, I

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards. Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud. Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Mix the Letter Cards, and have students rebuild it as they point to and say the letters.
